metadata.title: Effective binary catalysts of Brønsted acidic ionic liquids and stannous chloride dihydrate for melt polycondensation of <ce:small-caps>l</ce:small-caps>-lactic acid

Editor’s choice paper Effective binary catalysts of Brønsted acidic ionic liquids and stannous chloride dihydrate for melt polycondensation of l-lactic acid Qiaohong Peng a ⁎ Khalid Mahmood b Ying Wu b Zhengping Liu b ⁎ Li Wei c Hua Yuan a Ruixia Yang a a College of Materials Science and Engineering, Laboratory for New Fiber Materials and Modern Textile, Growing Base for State Key Laboratory, Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, PR China College of Materials Science and Engineering Laboratory for New Fiber Materials and Modern Textile Growing Base for State Key Laboratory Qingdao University Qingdao 266071 PR China b Institute of Polymer Chemistry and Physics of College of Chemistry, Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Conversion and Storage Materials, BNU Lab of Environmentally Friendly and Functional Polymer Materials, Beijing Normal University, Beijing 100875, PR China Institute of Polymer Chemistry and Physics of College of Chemistry Beijing Key Laboratory of Energy Conversion and Storage Materials BNU Lab of Environmentally Friendly and Functional Polymer Materials Beijing Normal University Beijing 100875 PR China c College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Qingdao University, Qingdao 266071, PR China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Qingdao University Qingdao 266071 PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Sulfonic acid-functionalized task-specific ionic liquids, named as Brønsted acidic ionic liquids (BAILs), stable to water, vacuum and heat, have shown excellent catalysis for esterification. BAILs with imidazolium cation and different anions were reasonably applied as catalysts or cocatalysts of stannous chloride dihydrate (SnCl2·2H2O) for melt polycondensation of l-lactic acid under relatively high vacuum and temperature. Binary catalysts of BAILs and SnCl2·2H2O always presented higher catalytic efficiency compared with the single component. We carefully investigated the influences of acidity and ionic structures of BAILs, amount of catalysts and pressure on polycondensation rate and molecular weight and properties of poly(l-lactic acid) (PLLA). Compared to the traditional binary catalysts of p-toluenesulfonic acid/SnCl2·2H2O, BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O could improve the thermal properties of the products. PLLAs with high molecular weight, good crystallinity, high optical purity and regular stereostructure were synthesized and characterized by GPC, DSC, 13C NMR, XRD and polarimeter. Keywords Brønsted acidic ionic liquids Binary catalysts Melt polycondensation Poly(l-lactic acid) 1 Introduction It is well-known to us that poly(l-lactic acid) (PLLA), having excellent biodegradability, biocompatibility, bioabsorbability and comparable properties and cost to polyethylene, polypropylene, polyethylene terephthalate or polyvinyl chloride, has been attracting considerable attention over the last several decades [1–7]. Generally, there are two ways to synthesize PLLA, direct polycondensation of l-lactic acid (LLA) and ring opening polymerization of l-lactide [8,9]. The latter monomer that is derived from the former needs more synthetic and handling steps, consequently resulting in much higher cost. Even so, ring opening polymerization of l-lactide is still the commercial producing method of PLLA due to the facile control of polymerization and molecular weight, and higher quality of the product thereof [10,11]. Alternatively, direct polycondensation of l-lactic acid often results in lower molecular weight, and relatively poor mechanical and thermal properties of the product, therefore adverse to the daily applications of the material. Researchers are always dealing with the problems that direct polycondensation of LLA faces by investigating catalysts, designing devices, adding additives, etc [12–16]. Application of catalyst is very important for a polymerization and its corresponding product. Transition metal compounds (e.g., SnCl2, ZnO, Fe(Lactate)3, Ti(OBu)4, etc.) and Brønsted acids (e.g., H2SO4, p-toluenesulfonic acid, CH3SO3H, perfluorinated resinsulfonic acid, etc.) are the mostly used catalysts for polycondensation reaction of LLA [16–19]. Yoon et al. used Ti(OBu)4 to catalyze direct polycondensation of LLA under different duration of decompression and obtained a weight average molecular weight of PLLA as high as 130kDa [13]. Takasu et al. applied water-stable catalysts, such as scandium trifluoromethanesulfonate Sc(OTf)3 and scandium trifluoromethanesulfonimide Sc(NTf2)3, to investigate one-step dehydration polycondensation of LLA at 130–170°C under the pressure of 0.3–3mmHg and obtained PLLA with weight average molecular weight over 100kDa [14]. In another study, binary catalysts for polycondensation of LLA were proved to be superior to the conventional single catalyst with regard to racemization and discoloration of the products [19,20]. Kimura et al. found that stannous chloride activated by various protonic acids can produce higher molecular weight PLLA (Mw ≥100,000) in a relatively short reaction time compared to single Sn(II)-based catalyst [18]. Later on, they investigated different binary catalyst systems consisting of stannous chloride and metal alkoxides as cocatalysts, e.g., Al(OiPr)3, Ti(OiPr)4, Y(OiPr)3, Si(OEt)4, Ge(OEt)4. The activity of these binary catalysts is slightly lower than stannous chloride/p-toluenesulfonic acid (SnCl2/TSA) in term of polymerization rate, but better on aspect of avoiding coloration of the PLLA product [20]. Ren et al. developed a safe and efficient composite catalyst of macroporous resin Amberlyst-15 and lactate to synthesize PLLA by melting polycondensation. PLLA with high molecular weight up to 110kDa were obtained and the crystallinity and optical purity of resulting products are better than those employing the traditional composite catalyst of SnCl2 and TSA [19]. However, the improvements with these catalysts are still limited. Therefore, new catalysts and/or catalyst systems need to be developed and investigated so that PLLA with excellent properties can be produced via direct polycondensation of l-lactic acid and finally applied in daily life. Brønsted acidic ionic liquids (BAILs), a class of functionalized ionic liquids, stable to water and air as compared with Lewis acidic ionic liquids such as chloroaluminate ionic liquids, have been extensively applied in polycondensations and condensation reactions of small molecules as both catalysts and solvents [21–25]. There are some disadvantages to use BAILs as solvents in polycondensation due to the highly different polarity between condensation polymers and BAILs, causing heterogeneous or even precipitation reactions [26]. BAILs have properties of negligible volatility, thermal and chemical stability, etc. that conventional ionic liquids possess [27–36]. Thus, BAILs could steadily stay in polycondensation system even under harsh conditions (e.g., high temperature, high vacuum) to maintain their catalytic performance. In addition, BAILs can be freely and precisely designed by modifying the structures of cations and anions to match the properties, especially the acidity, with polycondensations. In this study, we combined BAILs and SnCl2·2H2O together as binary catalysts for direct polycondensation of LLA. BAILs with imidazolium and different anionic structures and acidity show different catalytic efficiency and the yielded PLLAs also have different properties in regard to thermal transition temperature, optical purity and crystallinity. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Materials l-lactic acid (85%) was purchased from Tokyo Chemical Industry Co., Ltd. Stannous chloride dihydrate (98%), p-toluene sulfonic acid monohydrate (98%) and all the organic solvents were purchased from Beijing Chemical Works (Beijing, China). These chemicals were used as received. Brønsted acidic ionic liquids 1-(butyl-4′-sulfonic acid)-3-methylimidazolium trifluoromethanesulfonate [BSMIM][TFS], 1-(butyl-4′-sulfonic acid)-3-methylimidazolium hydrosulfate [BSMIM][HSO4], 1-(butyl-4′-sulfonic acid)-3-methylimidazolium p-toluenesulfonate [BSMIM][TS], 1-(butyl-4′-sulfonic acid)-3-methylimidazolium methanesulfonate [BSMIM][MS], and 1-(butyl-4′-sulfonic acid)-3-methylimidazolium fluoborate [BSMIM][BF4] were used as we previously synthesized (structures seen in Table 1 ) [26]. 2.2 Characterization NMR spectra were recorded at room temperature on a Bruker Avance 400MHz spectrometer using CDCl3 solutions containing 0.03% of tetramethylsilane (TMS) as an internal standard. Phase transition temperatures were recorded from differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) traces on a Mettler DSC1 instrument with liquid nitrogen cryostatic cooling (about 5mg samples, 10°C/min heating and cooling rates under 40mL/min nitrogen flow). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed with a METTLER STRAE SW 9.30 thermogravimetric analyzer under nitrogen flow at a heating rate of 10°C/min. The decomposition temperatures were measured at the onset point of the thermogravimetric curve. The molecular weight analysis was performed using a Polymer Laboratories gel permeation chromatograph (PL-GPC 50) equipped with PL gel mixed-B columns and RI detector. Chloroform was used as eluent at a flow rate of 1.0mL/min at 40°C. Polystyrene standards were used to calibrate the system. The specific optical rotation was measured in chloroform at a concentration of 1.0g/dL at 25°C using a PerkinElmer instruments Model 343 Polarimeter at a wavelength of 589nm. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was carried out on an X' Pert PRO MPD (PANalytical Co., the Netherlands), working at 40kV and 40mA, with Cu Kα radiation. Scans were made between Bragg angles of 4.5°–60° at a rate of 1°/min. 2.3 Preparation of oligo(l-lactic acid) 50mL of 85wt% aqueous solution of l-lactic acid was dehydrated at 160°C by gradually decrease the pressure from atmosphere to about 2kPa in 1h under magnetic stirring. Evaporation of water and prepolycondensation continued for another 5h and a transparent solid of oligo(l-lactic acid) (OLLA) was finally obtained after cooling down the product. The degree of polymerization of oligo(l-lactic acid) was about 7 based on calculation from 1H NMR spectrum (Fig. S1), and the number-average molecular weight was about 500Da. 2.4 Polycondensation of oligo(l-lactic acid) 6.00g of OLLA, 18.0mg (0.3wt%) of stannous chloride dihydrate and equimolar Brønsted acidic ionic liquid were added into a 25mL three-neck flask equipped with an air condenser and mechanical stirrer. Then the mixture was heated to 180°C in an oil bath under mechanical stirring and 2kPa, keeping the temperature of air condenser at 105°C for reflux of lactic acid and/or lactide. Gradually decrease the pressure to 800Pa, and then keep the conditions for 2.5–20h. After cooling down, the product was dissolved in 30mL of chloroform, and then precipitated from massive methanol or ethanol. White powder or fibres were obtained after filtered and vacuum drying. 3 Results and discussion As illustrated in Scheme 1 , poly(l-lactic acid) (PLLA) was synthesized through direct polycondensation in two steps: (1) Heating prepolymerization from commercial aqueous solution of l-lactic acid (LLA) to acquire oligo(l-lactic acid) (OLLA); (2) Post-polycondensation of OLLA catalyzed by binary catalysts of Brønsted acidic ionic liquids and stannous chloride dihydrate (BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O) to produce high molecular weight PLLA. Stannous compounds are the mostly used catalysts in polymerization of LLA. BAILs with different acidity, as cocatalysts, can activate stannous compounds. The synergistic catalysis was described by Kimura at al. as [18]: Sulfonic acid working as a ligand fill the open coordination sites of Sn(II) to prevent side reactions and discoloration and racemization of PLLA, at the same time stimulate dehydration and thus increase the rate of polycondensation. 3.1 Properties of BAILs Brønsted acids, e.g., H2SO4, p-toluenesulfonic acid (TSA), etc. are classical catalysts for esterification [37,38]. BAILs, having properties of both Brønsted acids and ionic liquids, are of moderate acidity, negligible volatility, stability, etc. Thus, BAILs could be stable and constant in polycondensation system, even under high temperature and high vacuum, keeping good catalytic performance. BAILs as cocatalysts together with SnCl2·2H2O are expected to catalyze melt polycondensation of LLA. In our previous work, Hammett acidity (H 0) and thermostability of BAILs have been investigated and discussed in depth [26]. In general, H 0 values of BAILs are in the range of −3.3 to −4.1, and the acid strength is in the following order: [BSMIM][TFS]>[BSMIM][BF4]>[BSMIM][TS]>[BSMIM][HSO4]≈[BSMIM][MS]; The onset decomposition temperatures of the BAILs are 357.1°C for [BSMIM][TFS], 320.5°C for [BSMIM][TS], 323.1°C for [BSMIM][HSO4], 328.9°C for [BSMIM][MS] and 107.7 and 319.4°C for [BSMIM][BF4] (Table 1, Fig. S2). Moderate acidity of BAILs was ascribed to the charge interaction between protons and anions. Decomposition of [BSMIM][BF4] between 107.7°C and 319.4°C produced zwitterion 1-(4′-butane sulfonate)-3-methylimidazolium (BSMIM) and superacid HBF4, which is concluded from 19F NMR and 1H NMR spectra of the decomposition product at the first stage (Fig. S3, Scheme S1). Hammett acidity and thermostability are considered to be the two most important properties of BAILs, which will remarkably influence their catalysis in polycondensation of l-lactic acid. 3.2 Melt polycondensation of LLA Aqueous solution of LLA was first dehydrated upon heating under vacuum, in order to remove a large amount of water that would possibly affect the activity of catalysts and acquire OLLA that couldn’t be readily evaporated under high temperature and high vacuum in the post-polycondensation step. Melt polycondensation of OLLA could be influenced by many factors, e.g., temperature, vacuum degree, type and quantity of catalyst, reaction time and device, etc. Herein, an air condenser that could be heated was equipped onto the reaction flask for effective reflux of lactide, monomer, dimer, trimer, etc. Consequently, relatively high yields were achieved even only 25mL of flask and small amount of OLLA were applied for the polycondensation system. Polymerization temperature applied here is 180°C, based on the previous reports [12,18], a little higher than the melting temperature of PLLA and a compromise between viscosity and control of side reactions. Thus, we first investigated the influence of vacuum degree on polycondensation of LLA. It is very important to remove produced water as soon as possible during polycondensation as a result of the small equilibrium constant of polyesterification. As exhibited in Fig. 1 , molecular weight of PLLA varied with vacuum degree remarkably. Under lower vacuum, water could not be removed effectively, resulting in lower molecular weight of PLLA within the same polymerization time. As the vacuum degree increased, the molecular weight of PLLA increased apparently. The molecular weight decreased oppositely when the pressure reached 0.6kPa since the oligomer and byproduct l-lactide could not be refluxed usefully under so high vacuum. Depolymerization of PLLA play a dominant role under such conditions, accompanying dramatic decrease of the polymer yield. According to the second-order rate equation − d c / d t = k ′ [ C O O H ] [ O H ] [ C a t a . ] , polycondensation rate is proportional to concentration of catalyst. As shown in Fig. 2 , growth rate of PLLA molecular weight has a great difference when using different quantities of catalysts. It took about 5, 10 and 15h, respectively, for molecular weights of PLLA to approach to 80kDa when 0.5wt%, 0.3wt% and 0.1wt% of catalysts were applied. Increasing the dosage of catalysts could effectively accelerate polycondensation reaction, whereas, the highest molecular weight of PLLA for each case has no big difference due to the difficulty of water removal originating from high molecular weight and high viscosity at the last stage of polycondensation. Melt polycondensation of LLA needs relatively long polymerization time for step growth of polymer chains. Application of catalyst(s) can significantly accelerate polycondensation of LLA and influence the properties of the product as well. We first investigated the cases with single catalyst (Table 2 , Run 1–3). Weight-average molecular weights (Mw) of PLLAs polymerized with [BSMIM][TS] and TSA were 11.2 and 18.4kDa, respectively, which greatly lower than that under the catalysis of SnCl2·2H2O and binary catalyst systems. And the appearance of the two PLLAs was like black wax. Other BAILs also presented the similar results. We infer that protonic acid catalyzed dehydration elimination of the end hydroxyl groups under such harsh conditions (180°C, 800Pa). Mw of PLLA polymerized with SnCl2·2H2O was 57.6kDa, but still not as high as that (over 81.5kDa) with binary catalysts. The molecular weights of PLLAs polymerized with TSA/SnCl2·2H2O and BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O binary catalysts did not show big difference. After PLLA was reprecipitated from methanol, the highest molecular weight could reach 118.1kDa from the catalysis of [BSMIM][HSO4]/SnCl2·2H2O. The polymer appearance all presented white fibre (Table 2, Run 4–11). These results confirmed the synergistic catalysis that was proposed by Kimura at al [18]. Fig. 3 shows the variation of PLLA molecular weights versus polymerization time in different binary catalyst systems. Polymerizations at the early stage are fast and the polymerization rate has a certain relationship with Hammett acidity (H 0). TSA having the strongest acidity results in the highest polymerization rate, whereas polymerization catalyzed by [BSMIM][MS]/SnCl2·2H2O has the lowest polymerization rate due to the weakest acidity of [BSMIM][MS]. The polymerization rates are not all proportional to acid strength of BAILs. As for [BSMIM][TFS], [BSMIM][TS] and [BSMIM][MS], the molecular weights of PLLA increase with the acidity of BAILs, indicating higher acidity of BAILs could lead to greater polymerization rate. However, [BSMIM][BF4] and [BSMIM][HSO4] are the exceptions. In the case of [BSMIM][BF4], [BSMIM][BF4] could be slowly decomposed to BSMIM and HBF4 at polymerization temperature due to its poor thermostability as mentioned above. So that HBF4, as a superacid [39], should accelerate polymerization of LLA more effectively than the sulfonic acid group of [BSMIM][BF4] (Scheme 2 ). For [BSMIM][HSO4], protons in both cation and anion would be well dissociated at polymerization temperature and then catalyze polycondensation of LLA at the same time (Scheme 2), leading to greater polymerization rate. At the late stage, all polymerizations dramatically slow down or even accompany with depolymerization due to the increasing viscosity and the difficulty of water removal thereof. The final molecular weights of PLLA are approximate to each other, in the range of 81.5–86.7kDa (Table 2, Fig. S4). And the polydispersity of polymer product is close to 2, the theoretical value calculated from a statistical approach [40]. 3.3 Properties of poly(l-lactic acid) Thermal transition temperatures of PLLA, with different molecular weights, prepared by using [BSMIM][BF4]/SnCl2·2H2O as catalysts were determined by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) (see in Fig. S5, S6 for original DSC curves). The relationships between glass transition temperature (Tg), crystallization temperature (Tc), melting temperature (Tm) and weight-average molecular weight of PLLA are plotted (Fig. S7). Tg, Tc, Tm of PLLA with Mw in the range of 4–67kDa, locate between 50 and 61°C, 87–129°C and 152–167°C, respectively. Thermal transition temperatures of PLLA increase with the increase of molecular weight, more obviously for lower molecular weight of PLLAs. Long-time polymerization increases the molecular weight of PLLA, but does not reduce their thermal performances. Thermal properties of PLLA, with molecular weights in the range of 81.5–86.7kDa, obtained from different BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O binary catalysts also exhibit some differences (Table 3 , Fig. S8). PLLAs obtained from BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O, compared with traditional binary catalysts of TSA/SnCl2·2H2O, have better thermal properties. As exhibited in Table 3, Tg and Tm increase with Hammett acidity values of BAILs excluding the case of [BSMIM][HSO4]. The possible reason for this phenomenon is that stronger acidity induced more uncertain reactions. For [BSMIM][HSO4], oxidability of sulfate group might generate more side reactions, resulting in the irregularity of polymer chain structure and finally lowering glass transition temperature and melting temperature. Crystallinity (γc) of PLLAs from different binary catalyst systems is in the range of 29–45%, and it seems that the crystallinity increase with strength of Hammett acidity of BAILs except for [BSMIM][BF4]. PLLA is a crystalline polymer due to the uniform stereostructure. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of PLLAs obtained from different binary catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 . Diffraction peaks around 2θ=16.9°, 19.0° and 22.4° are the characteristic reflections of PLLA crystals, in agreement with the reported results [41,42]. Broad peaks above baseline indicate the reflections of amorphous domains of PLLA. All PLLA products show similar XRD patterns, thus indicating similar crystalline structure. Optical properties of PLLAs from different binary catalyst systems are almost the same. Specific optical rotation ( [ α ] D 25 ) and optical purity (OP) of PLLAs are in the range of −144 to −142° and 91–92% ee, respectively, similar with the values of OLLA. It is suggested that binary catalysts did not change the optical properties of reactants during polymerization. From 13C NMR spectra of PLLAs polymerized by using different binary catalysts (Fig. 5 ), one can see that there is only one peak of carbonyl signal at 169.6ppm for all cases, suggesting isotactic L-sequence of lactate units in PLLA chains, referring to Thakur and Munson’s research [43]. The data indicate that binary catalysts of BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O scarcely induce racemization of lactate units during polycondensation. 4 Conclusions BAILs and SnCl2·2H2O together as a class of special binary catalysts were applied in melt polycondensation of l-lactic acid. All binary catalysts showed excellent catalytic efficiency and much higher molecular weight of PLLA could be prepared compared with the single catalyst. Moderate vacuum degree could balance water removal and side reactions to achieve the highest molecular weight. Higher catalyst concentrations could remarkably increase polymerization rate but not the final molecular weight. Acidity, thermal stability and structures of BAILs all have apparent influence on polymerization rate and properties of the polymer products. PLLAs obtained from BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O binary catalyst systems have higher thermal transition temperatures than that from TSA/SnCl2·2H2O due to the moderate acidity of BAILs. PLLAs having high optical purity and regular stereostructure were obtained by applying these binary catalysts. Acknowledgements The authors thank the National Science Foundation of China (Grant no. 50873016), Beijing Municipal Commission of Education, the Qingdao Postdoctoral Application Research Project (2015128), Program of Source Innovation of Applied Basic Research in Qingdao City, the Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities and Measuring Fund of Large Apparatus of Beijing Normal University for financial support. Appendix A Supplementary data Supplementary data associated with this article can be found, in the online version, at http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.mcat.2017.03.008. coredata.dc:description: Sulfonic acid-functionalized task-specific ionic liquids, named as Brønsted acidic ionic liquids (BAILs), stable to water, vacuum and heat, have shown excellent catalysis for esterification. BAILs with imidazolium cation and different anions were reasonably applied as catalysts or cocatalysts of stannous chloride dihydrate (SnCl2·2H2O) for melt polycondensation of l-lactic acid under relatively high vacuum and temperature. Binary catalysts of BAILs and SnCl2·2H2O always presented higher catalytic efficiency compared with the single component. We carefully investigated the influences of acidity and ionic structures of BAILs, amount of catalysts and pressure on polycondensation rate and molecular weight and properties of poly(l-lactic acid) (PLLA). Compared to the traditional binary catalysts of p-toluenesulfonic acid/SnCl2·2H2O, BAILs/SnCl2·2H2O could improve the thermal properties of the products. PLLAs with high molecular weight, good crystallinity, high optical purity and regular stereostructure were synthesized and characterized by GPC, DSC, 13C NMR, XRD and polarimeter.
coredata.dc:title: Effective binary catalysts of Brønsted acidic ionic liquids and stannous chloride dihydrate for melt polycondensation of l-lactic acid
